qas.question: On what date was the first TV show seen in the UK?
From where was the first TV show in the UK broadcasted?
How many lines made up the picture on Britain's earliest TV broadcasts?
When did Baird cease showing its programs on BBC?
When were both audio and video first broadcasted at the same time?
What was used, created by Logie John Baird, to make the Britain's first television broadcast?

plausible_answers.text: Simultaneous transmission of sound and picture

qas.question: What year did BBC radio go off the air?

context: Baird Television Ltd. made <b5_0>Britain's first television broadcast<b5_0/>, on <a0_0><a2_0>30<a2_0/> September 1929<a0_0/> from its studio in <a1_0>Long Acre, London<a1_0/>, via the BBC's London transmitter, using <b6_0>the electromechanical system<b6_0/> pioneered by John Logie Baird. This system used a vertically-scanned image of 30 lines – just enough resolution for a close-up of one person, and with a bandwidth low enough to use existing radio transmitters. <b7_0>Simultaneous transmission of sound and picture<b7_0/> was achieved on <a4_0>30 March 1930<a4_0/>, by using the BBC's new twin transmitter at Brookmans Park. By late <b8_0>1930<b8_0/>, 30 minutes of morning programmes were broadcast Monday to Friday, and 30 minutes at midnight on Tuesdays and Fridays, after BBC radio went off the air. <b9_0>Baird broadcasts via the BBC<b9_0/> continued until <a3_0>June 1932<a3_0/>.
